_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



N&B Midland Site is strongly committed to employees, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  Appropriate controls are implemented to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  The facility also coordinates with the City of Midland Fire Department and Midland LEPC which can provide additional emergency response expertise.



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

N&B Midland Site is a primarily chemical manufacturing, which also includes specialty products.

There are (2) covered processes, three (3) programs, and six (6) regulated substances present at N&B Midland Site.  



The regulated substances are listed below:

Regulated Substances:

Ethyl chloride

Ethyl Ether (diethyl ether)

Hydrogen Chloride

Methyl chloride

Methyl Ether

Propylene oxide



Worst and Alternative Case Scenario Selection:

There is one (2) toxic worst case and one (2) flammable worst case reported.  For the toxic worst-case scenario, the selection was based upon the furthest endpoint distance and the greatest impacted receptors.  For the flammable worst-case scenario, the selection was based upon the furthest endpoint distance and since there are no impacted receptors other variables were considered such as maximum capacities, location/distance to the fence line, and predominant wind direction. There are six (6) total alternate cases, two of which are flammable.





The General Accidental Release Prevention Program:

N&B Midland Site has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention

requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable company and governing agency requirements at the time of construction.  Modifications to existing structures are also done in compliance with applicable company standards and governing agency requirements.  Several processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 19 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the site.



Process Safety Information:

N&B Midland Site maintains detailed records of safety information that, among other things, describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment design associated with all covered processes.  Numerous types of information are available to supplement safety information, including Safety Data Sheets for materials used on-site, equipment and engineering design specifications, and applicable reactive chemicals testing.



Process Hazard Analysis:

N&B Midland Site conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  For initial screening and risk evaluation, calculations of The Dow Chemical Fire and Explosion and Chemical Exposure Indices are performed, and a Reactive Chemical and Process Hazard Analysis is conducted.  These methodologies are supplemented when needed with analyses that may include:  What if Analysis, Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), Fault Tree Analysis and Safer Technology and Alternative Analysis (STAA).  A team of qualified personnel performs the studies along with experts in engineering and process operations.  Any findings related to the hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures:

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, the N&B Michigan Operations Site maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.



Training:

N&B Midland Site has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity:

N&B Midland Site carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel receives specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change:

Written procedures are in place at N&B Midland Site to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training on the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews:

Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of existing processes are conducted as a regular practice at N&B Midland Site.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, and operating & maintenance procedures a

re suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits:

N&B Midland Site conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule and other applicable regulatory requirements are being followed and have been implemented properly.  Audits are conducted using an established schedule for the site.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



Incident Investigation:

N&B Midland Site promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root causes leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  The facility also investigates minor and near-miss type of incidents as a preventive measure.



Employee Participation:

N&B Midland Site operates on the premise that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues, to attend applicable reviews, and to recommend improvements.  Improvements are solicited and implemented as appropriate.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.



Contractors:

On occasion, N&B Midland Site hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction, and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  The facility has a strict program for informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes, as well as the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors are also required to inform the fac

ility of any hazards they may introduce or encounter while at the site.



Five-year Accident History:

Non-applicable.  



Emergency Response Plan

N&B Midland Site maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan documents all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is updated as necessary to reflect any pertinent changes within the processes at the facility that would require a modified emergency response.



The facility works with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the facility emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced in order to ensure that it is functioning properly at all times.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the accidental release prevention program.  Development of Environmental Health and Safety Work Processes, a concentrated Behavior-Based Safety effort, and company-wide Environmental Health & Safety goals are some of the major steps taken to improve safety at the Source.   N&B Midland Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.
